text: ਗੂਜਰੀ ਸ੍ਰੀ ਨਾਮਦੇਵ ਜੀ ਕੇ ਪਦੇ ਘਰੁ ੧
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Goojaree, Padas Of Naam Dayv Jee, First House:

transliteration.text: gūjarī srī nāmadēv jī kē padē ghar 1

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ੴ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

transliteration.text: ik ōunkār satigur prasād .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਜੌ ਰਾਜੁ ਦੇਹਿ ਤ ਕਵਨ ਬਡਾਈ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If You gave me an empire, then what glory would be in it for me?

transliteration.text: jau rāj dēh t kavan badāī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

The main spiritual message of Saint Namdev, just like the Sikh Gurus, was to emphasise the importance of living a married householder life and that through marriage, living in the world and meditating on God, one could attain enlightenment. Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

text: ਜੌ ਭੀਖ ਮੰਗਾਵਹਿ ਤ ਕਿਆ ਘਟਿ ਜਾਈ ॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If You made me beg for charity, what would it take away from me? ||1||

transliteration.text: jau bhīkh mangāvah t kiā ghat jāī .1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:

Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

text: ਤੂੰ ਹਰਿ ਭਜੁ ਮਨ ਮੇਰੇ ਪਦੁ ਨਿਰਬਾਨੁ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Meditate and vibrate upon the Lord, O my mind, and you shall obtain the state of Nirvaanaa.

transliteration.text: tūn har bhaj man mērē pad nirabān .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:

text: ਬਹੁਰਿ ਨ ਹੋਇ ਤੇਰਾ ਆਵਨ ਜਾਨੁ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: You shall not have to come and go in reincarnation any longer. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: bahur n hōi tērā āvan jān .1. rahāu .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਸਭ ਤੈ ਉਪਾਈ ਭਰਮ ਭੁਲਾਈ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: You created all, and You lead them astray in doubt.

transliteration.text: sabh tai upāī bharam bhulāī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. text: ਜਿਸ ਤੂੰ ਦੇਵਹਿ ਤਿਸਹਿ ਬੁਝਾਈ ॥੨॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: They alone understand, unto whom You give understanding. ||2||

transliteration.text: jis tūn dēvah tisah bujhāī .2.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰੁ ਮਿਲੈ ਤ ਸਹਸਾ ਜਾਈ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Meeting the True Guru, doubt is dispelled.

transliteration.text: satigur milai t sahasā jāī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. text: ਕਿਸੁ ਹਉ ਪੂਜਉ ਦੂਜਾ ਨਦਰਿ ਨ ਆਈ ॥੩॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Who else should I worship? I can see no other. ||3||

transliteration.text: kis hau pūjau dūjā nadar n āī .3.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. text: ਏਕੈ ਪਾਥਰ ਕੀਜੈ ਭਾਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One stone is lovingly decorated,

transliteration.text: ēkai pāthar kījai bhāu .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. text: ਦੂਜੈ ਪਾਥਰ ਧਰੀਐ ਪਾਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: while another stone is walked upon.

transliteration.text: dūjai pāthar dharīai pāu .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. text: ਜੇ ਓਹੁ ਦੇਉ ਤ ਓਹੁ ਭੀ ਦੇਵਾ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If one is a god, then the other must also be a god.

transliteration.text: jē ōh dēu t ōh bhī dēvā .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. text: ਕਹਿ ਨਾਮਦੇਉ ਹਮ ਹਰਿ ਕੀ ਸੇਵਾ ॥੪॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Naam Dayv, I serve the Lord. ||4||1||

transliteration.text: kah nāmadēu ham har kī sēvā .4.1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਗੂਜਰੀ ਘਰੁ ੧ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Goojaree, First House:

transliteration.text: gūjarī ghar 1 .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਮਲੈ ਨ ਲਾਛੈ ਪਾਰ ਮਲੋ ਪਰਮਲੀਓ ਬੈਠੋ ਰੀ ਆਈ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He does not have even a trace of impurity - He is beyond impurity. He is fragrantly scented - He has come to take His Seat in my mind.

transliteration.text: malai n lāshai pār malō paramalīō baithō rī āī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਆਵਤ ਕਿਨੈ ਨ ਪੇਖਿਓ ਕਵਨੈ ਜਾਣੈ ਰੀ ਬਾਈ ॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: No one saw Him come - who can know Him, O Siblings of Destiny? ||1||

transliteration.text: āvat kinai n pēkhiō kavanai jānai rī bāī .1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:

text: ਕਉਣੁ ਕਹੈ ਕਿਣਿ ਬੂਝੀਐ ਰਮਈਆ ਆਕੁਲੁ ਰੀ ਬਾਈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Who can describe Him? Who can understand Him? The all-pervading Lord has no ancestors, O Siblings of Destiny. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: kaun kahai kin būjhīai ramaīā ākul rī bāī .1. rahāu .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.description:

text: ਜਿਉ ਆਕਾਸੈ ਪੰਖੀਅਲੋ ਖੋਜੁ ਨਿਰਖਿਓ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: As the path of a bird's flight across the sky cannot be seen,

transliteration.text: jiu ākāsai pankhīalō khōj nirakhiō n jāī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

text: ਜਿਉ ਜਲ ਮਾਝੈ ਮਾਛਲੋ ਮਾਰਗੁ ਪੇਖਣੋ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥੨॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: and the path of a fish through the water cannot be seen;||2||

transliteration.text: jiu jal mājhai māshalō mārag pēkhanō n jāī .2.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

text: ਜਿਉ ਆਕਾਸੈ ਘੜੂਅਲੋ ਮ੍ਰਿਗ ਤ੍ਰਿਸਨਾ ਭਰਿਆ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: As the mirage leads one to mistake the sky for a pitcher filled with water

transliteration.text: jiu ākāsai gharūalō mrig trisanā bhariā .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

The main spiritual message of Saint Namdev, just like the Sikh Gurus, was to emphasise the importance of living a married householder life and that through marriage, living in the world and meditating on God, one could attain enlightenment. Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

text: ਨਾਮੇ ਚੇ ਸੁਆਮੀ ਬੀਠਲੋ ਜਿਨਿ ਤੀਨੈ ਜਰਿਆ ॥੩॥੨॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: - so is God, the Lord and Master of Naam Dayv, who fits these three comparisons. ||3||2||

transliteration.text: nāmē chē suāmī bīthalō jin tīnai jariā .3.2.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

The main spiritual message of Saint Namdev, just like the Sikh Gurus, was to emphasise the importance of living a married householder life and that through marriage, living in the world and meditating on God, one could attain enlightenment. Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

text: ਗੂਜਰੀ ਸ੍ਰੀ ਰਵਿਦਾਸ ਜੀ ਕੇ ਪਦੇ ਘਰੁ ੩
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Goojaree, Padas Of Ravi Daas Jee, Third House:

transliteration.text: gūjarī srī ravidās jī kē padē ghar 3

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ੴ ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

transliteration.text: ik ōunkār satigur prasād .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਦੂਧੁ ਤ ਬਛਰੈ ਥਨਹੁ ਬਿਟਾਰਿਓ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The calf has contaminated the milk in the teats.

transliteration.text: dūdh t basharai thanah bitāriō .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Ravidas
author.description: Saint Ravidas [1377 - 1528] was a Hindu shoemaker of the Chamar caste, who taught that a person is distinguished not by their caste, wealth or social status but instead by their actions.  Meerabai, the famous saint poetess is also said to have adopted Saint Ravidas as her Guru.

text: ਫੂਲੁ ਭਵਰਿ ਜਲੁ ਮੀਨਿ ਬਿਗਾਰਿਓ ॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The bumble bee has contaminated the flower, and the fish the water. ||1||

transliteration.text: phūl bhavar jal mīn bigāriō .1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. text: ਮਾਈ ਗੋਬਿੰਦ ਪੂਜਾ ਕਹਾ ਲੈ ਚਰਾਵਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: O mother, where shall I find any offering for the Lord's worship?

transliteration.text: māī gōbind pūjā kahā lai charāvau .

text: ਅਵਰੁ ਨ ਫੂਲੁ ਅਨੂਪੁ ਨ ਪਾਵਉ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I cannot find any other flowers worthy of the incomparable Lord. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: avar n phūl anūp n pāvau .1. rahāu .

section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The snakes encircle the sandalwood trees.

section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Poison and nectar dwell there together. ||2||

transliteration.text: bikh anmrit basah ik sangā .2.

translation.text: Even with incense, lamps, offerings of food and fragrant flowers,

translation.text: how are Your slaves to worship You? ||3||

section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I dedicate and offer my body and mind to You.

section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: By Guru's Grace, I attain the immaculate Lord. ||4||

transliteration.text: gur parasād niranjan pāvau .4.

text: ਪੂਜਾ ਅਰਚਾ ਆਹਿ ਨ ਤੋਰੀ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I cannot worship You, nor offer You flowers.

transliteration.text: pūjā arachā āh n tōrī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. text: ਕਹਿ ਰਵਿਦਾਸ ਕਵਨ ਗਤਿ ਮੋਰੀ ॥੫॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Ravi Daas, what shall my condition be hereafter? ||5||1||

transliteration.text: kah ravidās kavan gat mōrī .5.1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. text: ਗੂਜਰੀ ਸ੍ਰੀ ਤ੍ਰਿਲੋਚਨ ਜੀਉ ਕੇ ਪਦੇ ਘਰੁ ੧
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Goojaree, Padas Of Trilochan Jee, First House:

transliteration.text: gūjarī srī trilōchan jīu kē padē ghar 1

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

text: ਅੰਤਰੁ ਮਲਿ ਨਿਰਮਲੁ ਨਹੀ ਕੀਨਾ ਬਾਹਰਿ ਭੇਖ ਉਦਾਸੀ ॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: You have not cleansed the filth from within yourself, although outwardly, you wear the dress of a renunciate.

transliteration.text: antar mal niramal nahī kīnā bāhar bhēkh udāsī .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Trilochan
author.description:
Saint Trilochan [1267 - ?], a name which literally means three-eyed, the seer of the present, past and future, was a celebrated saint of the Hindu Vaishya caste. There are four hymns by him in the Guru Granth Sahib, in which he has condemned superficial rituals and pretentious renunciation and stressed the holiness of the heart.

Saint Trilochan always gave more importance to love and devotion in preference to selfish interests. He believed that he who is always occupied with problems relating to wealth and property would never become happy. He always served the saints at his residence with the utmost dedication and humility.

The exact place of birth of Bhagat Trilochan is not known. Some historians claim its Barsi near Sholapur, Maharastra and others claim its Uttar Pradesh. But it is an accepted fact that he spent most of his time in Maharashtra. The fact that two hymns of Saint Kabir constitute a dialogue between Saint Namdev and Saint Trilochan shows that these two saints were friends, and in fact it was Namdev who introduced Trilochan to his Guru who showed him the way to God.

text: ਹਿਰਦੈ ਕਮਲੁ ਘਟਿ ਬ੍ਰਹਮੁ ਨ ਚੀਨ੍ਹਾ ਕਾਹੇ ਭਇਆ ਸੰਨਿਆਸੀ ॥੧॥
section: Gujari - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: In the heart-lotus of your self, you have not recognized God - why have you become a Sannyaasee? ||1||

transliteration.text: hiradai kamal ghat braham n chīnhā kāhē bhaiā sanniāsī .1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Saint Trilochan
author.description:
Saint Trilochan [1267 - ?], a name which literally means three-eyed, the seer of the present, past and future, was a celebrated saint of the Hindu Vaishya caste. There are four hymns by him in the Guru Granth Sahib, in which he has condemned superficial rituals and pretentious renunciation and stressed the holiness of the heart.

Saint Trilochan always gave more importance to love and devotion in preference to selfish interests. He believed that he who is always occupied with problems relating to wealth and property would never become happy. He always served the saints at his residence with the utmost dedication and humility.

The exact place of birth of Bhagat Trilochan is not known. Some historians claim its Barsi near Sholapur, Maharastra and others claim its Uttar Pradesh. But it is an accepted fact that he spent most of his time in Maharashtra. The fact that two hymns of Saint Kabir constitute a dialogue between Saint Namdev and Saint Trilochan shows that these two saints were friends, and in fact it was Namdev who introduced Trilochan to his Guru who showed him the way to God.
